results.title: I'm feeling happy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Feelings”.
Children sing about and experience a number of things that bring happiness: The pleasures of smelling and eating good things, a bubbly bath, waking up on a sunny morning; the accomplishment of learning to drive, the inner satisfaction of being helpful without thought of reward and the warmth of sharing a friendship.

results.title: The World of the Koala
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Fauna”.
Koalas manage to survive exclusively on a diet of eucalyptus leaves, and in this program we go twenty metres up into the trees to observe the endearing behaviour of mother koalas and their young. The program also observes the habitat and wildlife surrounding the koala, as well as threats to its survival such as bushfires and tree felling.

results.title: Wombats
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Fauna”.
A program in which the two main species of wombat - the Common Wombat and the Hairy-Nosed Wombat, are compared. Also included is a reconstruction of the fascinating research done by a 15 year old schoolboy, in the 1960’s, who was the first person to venture into the long tunnels that the wombats dig as homes.

results.title: Crocodile
results.creator_credit: Peter Du Cane and David Moore
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Fauna”.
The hot tropical coast and hinterland of northern Australia support two types of crocodile with very different habitats and lifestyles. The program explores the life of the Salt Water Crocodile which inhabits estuaries and mangroves. In contrast, Johnstone’s Freshwater Crocodile, a shy animal, lives inland in seasonal rivers.

results.title: The Islands: Watery Outposts of Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Fauna”.
A visually stimulating look at a wide variety of Australian island habitats and wildlife, both above and below the tide line. Aerial, surface and underwater photography explores the world of the birds, reptiles, mammals and fish that inhabit the islands and coral reefs. Prominently featured is one of Australia’s natural wonders - the Great Barrier Reef.

results.title: The Tiny Carnivores
results.creator_credit: Peter Du Cane and David Moore
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Fauna”.
In this huge country most of the carnivorous mammals are tiny, and many are marsupials. Typically they are small but fierce predators of insects, spiders and grubs, but some - notably the native cats and Tasmanian Devil - are larger and more formidable. The program explores the behaviour of these animals.

results.title: The Little Marsupials
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Fauna”.
This program that contains rare and sometimes unique footage of little marsupials, including the amazing Honey Possum. Includes footage of the Numbats which feed exclusively on termites. Rare and endangered, the Numbats are the subject of research sponsored by the World Wildlife Fund. Features the marsupial gliders and the rare Red-Tailed Wambenger.

results.title: The Silver Gull
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Fauna”.
This program shows that the Silver Gulls have a fascinating behaviour and ecology. As well as their interaction with humans, we see their beautiful off-shore island nesting grounds where thousands of birds compete for territory. Sharing this idyllic habitat with the gulls are Sea-Lions, with quaint antics on shore and graceful gymnastics in the water.

results.title: Reptiles
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Fauna”.
Australia has some of the most interesting reptiles in the world. There are giant crocodiles, beautiful sea turtles and a variety of bizarre lizards, including the amazing Frilled Lizard. Even more remarkable are the snakes. Nine out of the ten most venomous snakes in the world are Australian. Included is rare footage of the recently discovered Small Scaled Snake. Narrated by David Moore.
